Award.AwardTitle: Special Year Workshops on Combinatorics and Complexity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Special Year Workshops on Combinatorics and Complexity award supports four workshops at the interface of the two fields during the periods of 2-6 October 2017, 13-17 November 2017, 5-9 February 2018, and 9-13 April 2018 at the Harvard Center of Mathematical Sciences and Applications (CMSA) in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Combinatorics and Computational Complexity have enjoyed a rich history of interaction leading to many significant developments in the two fields, such as the theories of NP-completeness, expander graphs, pseudorandomness, and property testing. Lately these fields have seen many new points of intersection such as in the development of the polynomial method (used, for example, in recent advances on the cap-set problem as well as in development of optimal list-decodable codes), the method of interlacing families of polynomials (yielding Ramanujan graphs and the resolution of the Kadison-Singer problem), and the theory of randomness extractors (yielding explicit constructions of Ramsey graphs. The base funding for the workshops will be provided by the Harvard CMSA and will enable the participation of senior visitors and a core group of leaders in the fields. Additional funding provided by this award will support the travel and local arrangements of graduate students, postdocs, junior researchers, members of underrepresented groups, and those without other forms of support.

Topics to be covered by the workshops include:
(1) Additive Combinatorics (organized by Ben Green, Swastik Kopparty, Ryan O'Donnell and Tamar Zeigler).
(2) Algebraic Methods in Combinatorics (organized by Zeev Dvir, Larry Guth and Shubhangi Saraf).
(3) Probabilistic and Extremal Combinatorics (organized by David Conlon and Benjamin Sudakov) and
(4) Coding and Information Theory (organized by Alexander Barg, Venkatesan Guruswami, and Mary Wootters).
Further information on the workshops and other special year activities may be found at http://cmsa.fas.harvard.edu/combinatorics/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the academic year 2017-2018, Harvard's Center for Mathematical Sciences and Applications (CMSA) hosted a special year on Combinatorics and Complexity. CMSA invited and hosted long-term visitors, postdoctoral researchers, and held four public lectures and four week-long workshops under this program. Funding for the workshops included an award from the National Science Foundation (NSF DMS 1742283). This report summarizes the activities conducted under this award.

The topics of the four workshops were: (1) Additive combinatorics, (2) Algebraic methods in combinatorics, (3) Probabilistic and extremal combinatorics, and (4) Coding and information theory. The choice of topics was driven by an aim to spread coverage of topics that lie in the intersection of the interests and current research in the fields of both Combinatorics and Computation Complexity. The choice of organizers of the workshops was also driven partially by the goal of bringing the two communities together, and this goal was then further adopted by the organizers in deciding on invitees and the workshop programs. We give details of the workshops below and then give our report on the outcomes.

The Workshop on Additive Combinatorics was held from October 2 to October 6, 2017. It was organized by Ben Green (Oxford), Swastik Kopparty (Rutgers), Ryan O?Donnell (CMU), and Tamar Ziegler (Hebrew University). The workshop featured 19 talks, each 50 minutes long. The workshop had 69 registered participants in addition to the four organizers and 19 speakers. Of these 69 registered participants, 11 were faculty, 14 postdoctoral researchers, 39 students (mostly graduate, but some undergraduate as well) and 5 others. 12 participants were supported by funds from the NSF award, 8 of whom were junior researchers (junior faculty, postdocs or graduate students) and 1 was female.

The Workshop on Algebraic Methods in Combinatorics was held from , November 13 to November 17, 2017. It was organized by Zeev Dvir (Princeton), Larry Guth (MIT) and Shubhangi Saraf (Rutgers). The workshop featured 16 one hour long talks along with an open problem session on the second day. The workshop had 78 registered participants in addition to the three organizers. Of these 21 were faculty, 10 postdoctoral researchers, 42 students and 5 others. 21 participants were supported by funds from the NSF award, 11 of whom were junior researchers (junior faculty, postdocs or graduate students) and 2 were female.

The Workshop on Probabilistic and Extremal Combinatorics was held from February 5 to February 9, 2018. It was organized by David Conlon (Oxford) and Benjamin Sudakov (ETH). The workshop featured 21 talks each 45 minutes long. The workshop had 98 registered participants in addition to the two organizers. Of these 21 were faculty, 21 postdoctoral researchers, 49 students and 7 others. 22 participants were supported by funds from the NSF award, 12 of whom were junior researchers (junior faculty, postdocs or graduate students) and 7 were female.

The Workshop on Coding and Information Theory was held from April 9 to April 13, 2018. It was organized by Alexander Barg (U. Maryland), Venkatesan Guruswami (CMU), and Mary Wootters (Stanford). It featured 29 talks varying in length from 30 minutes to one hour. It also featured a rump session and an open problem session. The workshop had 65 registered participants in addition to the three organizers. Of these 17 were faculty, 14 postdoctoral researchers, 26 students and 8 others. 17 participants were supported by funds from the NSF award, 10 of whom were junior researchers (junior faculty, postdocs or graduate students) and 2 were female.

Outcome

Based on the registration and the attendance at the workshop, the workshops were extremely successful. For context, the conference was held in a room that could seat 80 people, but in several talks the seating capacity was exceeded and attendees were sitting on the floor. (Many people just showed up for talks without registering even though there was no charge for registration.) The average attendance in talks was in the 50-60 person range. Furthermore in each workshop the majority of the registrants were students indicating that the workshops managed to hit this crucial target audience.

The funding for the workshops included three components: Funding from CMSA, from the Harvard theory group, and from NSF. Funding from CMSA and the Harvard theory group enabled the presence of long term and medium term visitors such as Noga Alon, Jacob Fox, Venkatesan Guruswami and Benjamin Sudakov along with three postdoctoral researchers, Mrinal Kumar, Guy Moshkovitz and Noam Solomon working in the area of Combinatorics and Computational Complexity. The CMSA funding also led to funding for the organizers of the workshops and to some of the senior researchers. The NSF funding was spent mostly on the junior researchers including some graduate students postdoctoral researchers. Indeed the NSF funding was critical in improving the outreach of the program to address junior researchers in the fields.
